item.title: $SEV - Aptera. Electric car you never have to plug in — 77 replies — 41.9/hr
item.content:encoded:
$SEV - Aptera. Electric car you never have to plug in

Open thread • Replies: 77 • Updated: 2026-02-27 09:39 UTC

OP

This is a risky startup company, but FINALLY this year they are shipping their product. This summer, in fact. They just finished a final round of dilution a month ago, and the stock just hit a critical point where it’s actively in recovery.

It’s a real car, a product that *will* ship that nerds are geeking out about, and it appears now someone big is starting to slowly acquire it.

The first model will have its flaws, but it’s an electric car that can run off the solar panels on its roof. No one has ever done that before.

And the entire fucking company’s marketcap, this Nasdaq company, is $70 million.

You’re welcome.

(Disclosure: I obviously own some moderate sized bags of this, as should you)

Early replies (first 3)

61902124
Go look the shit up on YouTube and do some research. Tech bros will buy out the first line of these as fun geek toys, and by the second and third iterations, it’s gonna start getting serious. The big boys (aka Tesla) cannot afford to let this company get too large under their toes. They’ll acquire the stock and buy them out before that happen. That’s my thesis, anyway. The company’s not perfect, it has issues. But it’s worth more than $70 million for damn sure.

61902143
>>61902111
I believe that oil,nat gas, nuclear energy, clean coal is going to make a comeback, and that the "green" stuff wont be " cool" anymore, I avoid betting on anyting "green". At least I do not think the US will care about solar and wind turbines and all that crap anymore. In the Eu, that car would look ridicolous and nobody would drive it., btw in Eu we drive diesel.

61902157
>>61902124
Almost had me interested before I saw that monstrosity

>>61907929

61908205
>>61908115

>>61907984

>>61908120
A baggie maybe, but not desperate. I just got into this a few days ago, so I’m actually up slightly. I’m just enjoying having a /biz/ where we can share ideas that aren’t the shitcoin du jour.

61908329
>>61908205
>if one of the big boys wants to buy out this stock, that doesn’t bother me as a recent investor
No you moron, I'm trying to say that in all likelihood that WON'T happen. Because there's lots of startups and most don't have the capital or connections to make it through and break into success.
If you want people to invest in this particular stock then convince us that they're special.

2. OP is replying A LOT which is mega sus
3. it is rebounding a bit
4. OP is probably a fag baiting plebs into buying his bags (ie. selling calls, while dumping shares or selling puts and buying shares aka the gay price action)
5. i dont know what to do. that car is ugly as fuck. but even if they somehow match their next competitor MC that makes this an easy 100x

No one is going to throw money at this just because it's an EV company like they were back then. Anything BYD puts out absolutely creams this garbage at like 1/5 the price.

Oh shit that’s awesome, an actual enthusiast. You must be a decently well off tech bro to pre-order something like that; I think that’ll be the first wave. The practical crowd will come later, but just imagine how cool an SUV model you can camp in will be - even if they have to cut some efficiency and it’ll need to be third gen or further.

And besides what these idiots are saying, a vehicle that can power itself by the literal sun is neat. I’m looking forward to the first retard who drives across the coast on solar power alone - though it’ll take a while. Anyway, thanks for chipping in.

>>61908857
That’s a good way to look at it because despite how neat the tech is, this company has real issues. But what startup company doesn’t. Still, I’m in for my money.

61909028
>>61908843
>EV market is shrinking
Only in the US, and only in the US because the federal rebate went away, and companies such as Ford thought people actually wanted $140k electric pickup trucks.

61909297

cheers OP

61909905
>>61909297

it's the usual shit where people think whatever they own is worth X because someone said it is worth X, without ever having checked if anyone is actually buying it for that price. similar to retards thinking their pokemon card is worth a million.
prices will have to come down, and some people will have to pay the price for their greed.

61909986
>you know what happens next
Nothing.

61910072
>>61909912
When rates are under 7% they're too low to be beneficial to renters.

61910074
Home prices are still growing ~2.8%/yr since May 2022, but signs of a round-off top have already appeared. Momentum is decreasing since Sep 2023. For the span of 2012 and 2020-2022 home sales prices increased so euphorically it put us at 2007 levels of momentum & momentum change.

What happens next? Between 4-10 years, coincidently aligned with the beginning window of mass boomer die-off, prices and rates will crash to a new generational low. They WONT lower prices and there WONT be buyers. There will clearly be a socially uncomfortable liquidity crisis spanning 15-20 years until they're all dead. Look to buy in 2030ish at the earliest. But you are likely to get a much better deal in 2035-2040.

None of this needed to happen if boomers didn't pump their worthless hooms during the fake manufactured virus scare. They did this. On purpose.

61910098
>>61910074

I get 3% cash back on every credit card purchase I make and pay 0% interest. Whenever I get a new credit card, I usually get a $200 bonus cash back, plus 0% APR for 12+ months.

>>61905079

>>61905079
Horrible advice. Buy with credit cards that offer rewards, then pay them off in full every month before due date. Literal free money and my credit score has been soaring. Fuck wish id done this a decade ago.

61908821
>>61905079

>can't control their spending
>have 5 credit cards
>have no savings or long term investments
>make $15 an hour

61908832
>>61908654

You gotta remember the people who need his advice probably have like sub 600 credit and ridiculous interest rates.

item.content:encoded:
FED ENDS THE SILVER

Open thread • Replies: 17 • Updated: 2026-02-27 08:12 UTC

OP

Rock collecting is not investing, and all dwarves flooding the precious metal threads will end up rugged just like the last time. Yes, I'm jinxing it.

Can I order buy anything with silver — like I can do with Bitcoin near instantly, just sending the money to someone in Japan in a flash? No? Then your silver is not real money, you might as well collect Pokémon cards because it is unironically easier to turn them into cash.

The precious metal fad killed bitcoin, there is no explanation for the wave of liquidations besides whales "diversifying" their asset.
